questions.text: A 45 year old male presents with recurrent falls. MRI brain shows atrophy of mid-brain what is probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP). Progressive Supranuclear Palsy is a rare neurodegenerative disorder characterized by prominent midbrain atrophy, often described as the "hummingbird" or "penguin" sign on MRI. This condition typically presents with symptoms such as postural instability, frequent falls (particularly backward), and a vertical gaze palsy (difficulty moving the eyes up and down). These clinical features are consistent with the recurrent falls seen in this patient. The midbrain atrophy observed on MRI is a hallmark imaging finding that strongly supports the diagnosis of PSP. Why other options are incorrect: A. Multiple System Atrophy (MSA): MSA is a progressive neurodegenerative disorder that primarily affects the autonomic nervous system and motor function. While it can cause falls, the MRI findings in MSA typically show atrophy in the cerebellum, brainstem, or putamen rather than isolated midbrain atrophy. Additionally, patients often present with symptoms like parkinsonism, autonomic dysfunction, or cerebellar ataxia, which were not highlighted in this case. C. Lewy Body Dementia (LBD): Lewy Body Dementia is characterized by progressive cognitive decline, fluctuating levels of alertness, visual hallucinations, and parkinsonism. Falls can occur in LBD, but the hallmark imaging findings include generalized cortical atrophy or changes in the occipital lobe rather than midbrain atrophy. The clinical presentation and imaging findings in this case are more consistent with PSP than LBD. D. Shy-Drager Syndrome (a variant of MSA): Shy-Drager Syndrome is an older term used for the autonomic-dominant subtype of MSA. It involves significant autonomic dysfunction, such as orthostatic hypotension, along with parkinsonian or cerebellar symptoms. The imaging findings in Shy-Drager Syndrome typically show brainstem or cerebellar involvement rather than midbrain atrophy, making this an unlikely diagnosis for the described case.

questions.text: All of the following are Non-motor features of Parkinson’s disease, except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Loss of taste. Loss of taste is not a recognized non-motor feature of Parkinson’s disease (PD). While PD can affect many non-motor domains, including sensory perception, the loss of taste is uncommon and not typically associated with the disease. Any reported changes in taste perception in PD patients are more likely secondary to other factors, such as medications or co-existing conditions, rather than a direct feature of the disease itself. Why other options are incorrect: A. Sleep disturbances: Sleep disorders are a well-documented non-motor feature of Parkinson’s disease. Common issues include rapid eye movement (REM) sleep behavior disorder, insomnia, restless leg syndrome, and excessive daytime sleepiness. These disturbances can significantly impact the quality of life in PD patients and are often some of the earliest non-motor symptoms to appear. B. Cognitive impairment: Cognitive decline and dementia can develop in the later stages of Parkinson’s disease. Mild cognitive impairment is also common and may include difficulties with attention, executive functioning, or memory. These features are part of the non-motor spectrum of the disease and contribute to its overall burden. D. Loss of smell: Loss of smell (anosmia or hyposmia) is a hallmark non-motor feature of Parkinson’s disease and is often one of the earliest symptoms, sometimes preceding motor manifestations by years. This symptom is related to the degeneration of the olfactory pathways and is a key clue in the early diagnosis of PD.

choices.text: May appear in lips,tongue and jaw

questions.text: Which of the following is false about Rest tremors in PD?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Appear bilaterally first distally. Rest tremors in Parkinson’s disease (PD) typically begin unilaterally, often in one hand or foot, and then progress to involve the other side over time. This asymmetry is a hallmark feature of PD and helps differentiate it from other conditions that may present with tremors. The tremor is most evident at rest and improves with voluntary movement. It is commonly referred to as a "pill-rolling" tremor because of its characteristic appearance. Why other options are incorrect: A. Frequency of 4 to 6 Hz: This is correct. Rest tremors in PD usually have a frequency of 4 to 6 Hz, which is slower than other types of tremors, such as essential tremors. This specific frequency is a defining characteristic of the tremors seen in Parkinson’s disease. C. May appear in lips, tongue, and jaw: This is correct. Rest tremors in PD can also involve the lips, tongue, and jaw, though these areas are less commonly affected compared to the limbs. Tremors in these regions can sometimes cause visible facial movements. D. Spares head and neck: This is correct. Rest tremors in PD typically spare the head and neck. Tremors in the head are more commonly associated with essential tremor rather than Parkinson’s disease. This distinction is often helpful in the differential diagnosis of tremor disorders.

questions.text: The commonest type of parkinsonism with is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Idiopathic. Idiopathic Parkinson’s disease (PD) is the most common type of parkinsonism with a known etiology, accounting for the majority of cases. While the exact cause of idiopathic PD remains unknown, it is associated with the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra of the brain. Environmental and genetic factors may contribute, but the term "idiopathic" specifically refers to cases where no definitive cause can be identified. This form of parkinsonism is characterized by the classic motor features of tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability, along with a range of non-motor symptoms. Why other options are incorrect: A. Head injury: While head trauma can lead to parkinsonism, it is far less common than idiopathic Parkinson’s disease. Repeated head injuries, as seen in chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE), may cause symptoms similar to PD, but this is a rare etiology compared to idiopathic cases. B. Familial: Familial parkinsonism refers to cases caused by specific genetic mutations, such as mutations in the SNCA, LRRK2, or PARK genes. Although familial forms are well-documented, they are relatively uncommon and account for only a small percentage of all cases of parkinsonism. D. Sporadic: While sporadic Parkinson’s disease might sound similar to idiopathic PD, sporadic typically refers to cases without a clear genetic link but can still have environmental or secondary causes. Idiopathic PD, on the other hand, explicitly denotes the absence of any identifiable underlying cause and is more prevalent.

questions.text: Parkinsonism may be caused by all except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Phenytoin sodium. Phenytoin sodium, an anticonvulsant used to manage seizures, does not typically cause parkinsonism. Unlike drugs that deplete dopamine or block dopamine receptors, phenytoin does not interfere with the dopaminergic pathways in the basal ganglia, which are central to the pathogenesis of parkinsonism. Therefore, it is not associated with drug-induced parkinsonism. Why other options are incorrect: A. Reserpine: Reserpine depletes dopamine stores in presynaptic nerve terminals by inhibiting the vesicular monoamine transporter (VMAT). This reduction in dopamine levels can lead to parkinsonism, as dopamine is critical for normal motor function. Reserpine-induced parkinsonism is a well-recognized side effect. B. Alpha methyldopa: Alpha methyldopa, an antihypertensive agent, can induce parkinsonism through its effect on the central nervous system. It inhibits dopa decarboxylase, an enzyme involved in dopamine synthesis, which may lead to reduced dopamine availability and subsequent parkinsonian symptoms. C. Metoclopramide: Metoclopramide, a dopamine receptor antagonist often used as an antiemetic and prokinetic agent, can cause parkinsonism as a side effect. By blocking dopamine D2 receptors in the basal ganglia, metoclopramide disrupts normal dopaminergic signaling, leading to drug-induced parkinsonism.

questions.text: Parkinsonism symptoms develop when striatal dopamine depletion reaches how much of normal ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 50-70%. Parkinsonism symptoms typically develop when striatal dopamine levels are reduced by 50-70% of normal levels. The basal ganglia, specifically the striatum, rely on dopamine from the substantia nigra to regulate motor function. The brain has a remarkable compensatory ability, and symptoms do not usually manifest until there is significant dopamine depletion. At this threshold, motor symptoms such as tremor, bradykinesia, rigidity, and postural instability begin to appear, indicating that the compensatory mechanisms can no longer maintain normal function. Why other options are incorrect: A. 10-30%: A 10-30% reduction in dopamine levels is too mild to cause noticeable parkinsonism symptoms. The brain compensates effectively at this stage, and individuals remain asymptomatic due to functional redundancy in the dopaminergic system. B. 30-50%: A 30-50% reduction in dopamine may begin to impair function, but it is not sufficient to produce overt clinical symptoms in most individuals. The motor symptoms of parkinsonism usually emerge only when depletion exceeds this level. D. 70-90%: While dopamine depletion in the range of 70-90% is associated with severe motor symptoms and progression of Parkinson’s disease, symptoms generally start to manifest earlier, at 50-70% depletion. By the time dopamine levels drop to 70-90%, the disease is typically in an advanced stage with significant disability.

questions.text: Testing for postural instability in PD is done by ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Pull test. The pull test is a clinical examination used to assess postural instability in patients with Parkinson’s disease (PD). During this test, the examiner stands behind the patient and gives a sudden backward pull on the patient’s shoulders, asking them to maintain their balance. In a healthy individual, balance is quickly regained with minimal steps. In Parkinson’s disease, due to impaired postural reflexes, the patient may take several steps backward or even fall. This test is part of the Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) and is a standard tool for evaluating postural stability in PD. Why other options are incorrect: A. Swing test: There is no recognized "swing test" used to assess postural instability in Parkinson’s disease. This term may refer to other unrelated assessments or contexts but is not relevant for evaluating balance or postural reflexes in PD. B. Push test: The push test is similar in concept to the pull test but is not commonly used in clinical practice for Parkinson’s disease. The pull test is the standardized method and is part of the formal assessment for postural instability in PD. D. Lift test: There is no "lift test" associated with postural instability testing in Parkinson’s disease. This option is unrelated to the evaluation of balance or reflexes in the condition.

questions.text: Which of the following is most useful in the diagnosis of parkinsonism :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Clinical examination. Clinical examination is the most useful tool in diagnosing parkinsonism. Parkinsonism is a clinical syndrome characterized by bradykinesia, rigidity, tremor (typically at rest), and postural instability. These hallmark motor symptoms are best identified through a detailed physical and neurological examination by a clinician. Clinical examination also helps differentiate parkinsonism from other conditions with similar features, such as essential tremor or atypical parkinsonian syndromes. The Unified Parkinson's Disease Rating Scale (UPDRS) is often used as part of the assessment. Imaging and other tests are generally not required for the diagnosis of idiopathic Parkinson's disease unless there is a need to rule out secondary causes. Why other options are incorrect: A. EEG and CT scan: Neither EEG nor CT scan is routinely used in diagnosing parkinsonism. CT scans may help exclude other structural brain abnormalities, such as strokes or tumors, that could mimic parkinsonism, but they are not diagnostic for Parkinson's disease or other parkinsonian syndromes. EEG is rarely relevant unless there is a suspicion of coexisting seizure disorders or other neurological conditions unrelated to parkinsonism. C. History: While the patient’s history is important, it is typically used in conjunction with the clinical examination. History alone cannot confirm the diagnosis of parkinsonism, as it may not provide definitive evidence of the key motor symptoms. However, history is useful for identifying risk factors, such as drug exposure or head trauma, that could contribute to secondary parkinsonism. D. Therapeutic response to drugs: Response to dopaminergic therapy (e.g., levodopa) can support the diagnosis of idiopathic Parkinson’s disease, as most patients with PD exhibit significant improvement. However, therapeutic response is not a standalone diagnostic criterion, as other forms of parkinsonism, such as drug-induced or atypical parkinsonism, may not respond well to treatment.

choices.text: Impaired vibration in distal Lower limb

questions.text: The following may be considered non motor manifestations of PD:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Anosmia. Anosmia (loss of smell) is a well-recognized non-motor manifestation of Parkinson’s disease (PD) and often appears years before the onset of motor symptoms. It is associated with degeneration in the olfactory bulb and related brain regions, which are among the first areas affected in PD. Anosmia is considered a prodromal feature of the disease and can aid in early diagnosis, particularly in individuals at high risk. Why other options are incorrect: A. Impaired vibration in distal lower limb: Impaired vibration sense is not a common feature of Parkinson’s disease. Sensory disturbances are generally mild or absent in PD. If present, they may suggest a peripheral neuropathy or an unrelated condition rather than a direct manifestation of Parkinson’s disease. B. Seizures: Seizures are not a characteristic feature of Parkinson’s disease. While neurodegenerative conditions may occasionally increase seizure risk, seizures are not typically associated with PD. Their presence should prompt an investigation for other underlying conditions, such as structural brain lesions or epilepsy. C. Optic atrophy: Optic atrophy is not seen in Parkinson’s disease. Visual disturbances in PD are usually due to dysfunction in eye movement or contrast sensitivity rather than structural abnormalities like optic atrophy. Optic atrophy may indicate other neurological conditions, such as multiple sclerosis or hereditary optic neuropathies.

questions.text: Which of the following symptoms respond poorly to therapy in PD ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Balance difficulties. Balance difficulties, or postural instability, respond poorly to therapy in Parkinson’s disease (PD). This symptom typically emerges in the later stages of the disease and is caused by progressive degeneration of non-dopaminergic systems, including cholinergic pathways. As a result, dopaminergic therapies, such as levodopa, which target dopamine deficiency, have limited efficacy in addressing balance issues. Postural instability often leads to falls and is a major contributor to disability and reduced quality of life in PD patients. Non-pharmacological interventions, such as physical therapy and balance training, are essential for managing this symptom. Why other options are incorrect: A. Bradykinesia: Bradykinesia, or slowness of movement, is one of the cardinal motor symptoms of Parkinson’s disease and responds well to dopaminergic therapies like levodopa. These medications replenish dopamine levels, improving the execution and speed of voluntary movements. B. Abnormal posture: Abnormal posture, such as stooped posture, is seen in PD and is partially responsive to dopaminergic therapy. However, it may also have contributions from non-dopaminergic pathways or structural changes in muscles and joints, limiting the extent of improvement with medication alone. Physical therapy and posture training can further help manage this symptom. D. Rigidity: Rigidity, or increased muscle tone, is another hallmark feature of Parkinson’s disease and typically responds well to dopaminergic therapy. Levodopa and other dopamine-augmenting medications can alleviate rigidity, improving the patient’s overall comfort and mobility.

choices.text: Deep brain stimulation of globus pallidus interna
Deep brain stimulation of globus pallidus externa
Deep brain stimulation of Substantia nigra
Deep brain stimulation of Caudate nucleus

questions.text: Surgical treatment of parkinson’s disease consists of-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Deep brain stimulation of globus pallidus interna. Deep brain stimulation (DBS) of the globus pallidus interna (GPi) is a well-established surgical treatment for Parkinson's disease (PD). This approach involves implanting electrodes in the GPi to modulate abnormal neural activity, particularly in the basal ganglia circuits responsible for motor control. DBS of the GPi has been shown to significantly reduce motor symptoms such as tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia, particularly in patients who are not responding well to medication. It is typically used in advanced PD stages, when pharmacological treatments no longer provide adequate symptom relief. Why other options are incorrect: B. Deep brain stimulation of globus pallidus externa: Deep brain stimulation of the globus pallidus externa (GPe) is not typically used in the treatment of Parkinson’s disease. While research is ongoing, the GPi is more commonly targeted in clinical practice due to its central role in modulating motor function through its connections with other structures of the basal ganglia. C. Deep brain stimulation of Substantia nigra: DBS of the substantia nigra is not a standard treatment for Parkinson’s disease. While the substantia nigra plays a key role in dopamine production, DBS is not typically targeted here. The degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra leads to reduced dopamine in the striatum, but DBS is more effective when used to modulate other regions, such as the GPi or subthalamic nucleus. D. Deep brain stimulation of Caudate nucleus: The caudate nucleus is part of the striatum and involved in motor control, but DBS is not typically used here for Parkinson’s disease. The caudate is more involved in other aspects of movement and cognitive control, and DBS is generally directed at structures like the GPi or subthalamic nucleus, which are more directly involved in the motor dysfunction seen in PD.

questions.text: Most common cause of secondary parkinsonism is-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Antipsychotic drugs. The most common cause of secondary parkinsonism is the use of antipsychotic drugs, particularly those that block dopamine receptors in the brain. This drug-induced parkinsonism, also known as drug-induced parkinsonism (DIP), is often seen with first-generation antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol) and, to a lesser extent, second-generation antipsychotics (e.g., risperidone). These medications can interfere with the dopaminergic pathways in the basal ganglia, leading to symptoms such as tremor, rigidity, bradykinesia, and postural instability that resemble Parkinson’s disease. The symptoms typically improve when the offending drug is discontinued or switched to a different medication. Why other options are incorrect: A. Carbon monoxide: Carbon monoxide poisoning can cause encephalopathy and may result in neurological symptoms, including parkinsonism, but it is a rare cause compared to drug-induced parkinsonism. Carbon monoxide exposure affects the basal ganglia, which can lead to movement disorders, but it is much less common as a cause of secondary parkinsonism. B. Manganese: Chronic exposure to high levels of manganese, typically through occupational hazards (e.g., mining or welding), can lead to a form of parkinsonism known as manganism. While this can result in symptoms similar to PD, it is far less common than drug-induced parkinsonism. D. Genetic defect: Genetic defects typically lead to primary parkinsonism, such as in familial forms of Parkinson’s disease. Secondary parkinsonism is caused by environmental factors or medical conditions, not genetic defects. Therefore, genetic defects are not a common cause of secondary parkinsonism.

choices.text: Manifest as postural or action tremor

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding essential tremors?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Frequency is 4 to 6 Hz. This statement is false regarding essential tremor. The typical frequency of essential tremor is 6 to 12 Hz, not 4 to 6 Hz. Essential tremor is a common movement disorder that primarily presents as a postural or action tremor, usually affecting the hands, head, or voice. A tremor with a frequency in the range of 4 to 6 Hz is more characteristic of parkinsonian tremors, particularly those seen in Parkinson’s disease. Why other options are incorrect: A. It is the commonest movement disorder: This statement is true. Essential tremor is indeed the most common movement disorder, affecting a large percentage of the population, particularly those over the age of 60. It is often misdiagnosed as Parkinson’s disease, but it is more widespread. B. Manifest as postural or action tremor: This statement is true. Essential tremor typically manifests as a postural tremor (tremor when holding a position against gravity) or action tremor (tremor during voluntary movements such as writing, eating, or holding objects). It usually affects the hands and arms but can also involve the head, voice, and other parts of the body. C. Treatment is propranolol: This statement is true. Propranolol, a beta-blocker, is commonly used to treat essential tremor. It helps reduce tremor amplitude by blocking the beta-adrenergic receptors that can exacerbate tremor symptoms. Other treatments, such as primidone, are also used, but propranolol remains one of the most effective and commonly prescribed medications.

choices.text: Chorea is due to lesion in caudate nucleus
Hemiballismus is due to lesion in subthalamic nucleus
Dystonia is due to lesion in putamen
Athetosis is due to lesion in globus pallidus

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding hyperkinetic movement disorders?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Dystonia is due to lesion in putamen. This statement is false. Dystonia is primarily due to dysfunction in the basal ganglia but is more commonly associated with lesions or dysfunction in the globus pallidus and the putamen. However, the pathophysiology of dystonia is not exclusively linked to the putamen. Rather, dystonia involves a complex interaction between several parts of the basal ganglia, including the globus pallidus and other structures like the thalamus and motor cortex. Thus, lesions in the putamen alone do not typically cause dystonia, although changes in its activity may contribute. Why other options are incorrect: A. Chorea is due to lesion in caudate nucleus: This statement is true. Chorea, characterized by involuntary, rapid, and irregular movements, is often caused by damage to the caudate nucleus, which is part of the basal ganglia. Chorea is seen in conditions like Huntington's disease, where the caudate nucleus undergoes progressive degeneration, leading to these movement abnormalities. B. Hemiballismus is due to lesion in subthalamic nucleus: This statement is true. Hemiballismus, a condition characterized by violent, involuntary, and flinging movements of one side of the body, is typically caused by a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus. The subthalamic nucleus plays a critical role in the regulation of motor control, and its damage disrupts the basal ganglia's feedback loop, leading to hyperkinetic movements like hemiballismus. D. Athetosis is due to lesion in globus pallidus: This statement is true. Athetosis, characterized by slow, writhing movements, particularly of the hands and feet, is often associated with lesions in the globus pallidus, another structure of the basal ganglia. The globus pallidus helps regulate smooth motor control, and when it is damaged, it can lead to the abnormal, continuous movements seen in athetosis.

choices.text: Symptoms becomes worse in the evening or night

questions.text: All of the following are core symptoms for diagnosis of Restless leg syndrome EXCEPT
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Symptoms improved by alcohol. This statement is false. In fact, alcohol typically worsens the symptoms of Restless Leg Syndrome (RLS) rather than improving them. People with RLS may experience an increase in symptoms after consuming alcohol, leading to further discomfort and restlessness. The core symptoms of RLS are characterized by unpleasant sensations in the legs, an urge to move the legs, and a pattern of symptoms that worsen during rest and are relieved by movement. Alcohol does not help with symptom relief and is not a factor associated with the diagnosis of RLS. Why other options are incorrect: A. Unpleasant sensations on the legs: This statement is true. One of the hallmark symptoms of Restless Leg Syndrome is an unpleasant sensation or discomfort in the legs, often described as crawling, tingling, itching, or aching. These sensations are typically felt deep within the legs and are a core symptom necessary for diagnosis. B. Symptoms begin with rest: This statement is true. A key feature of Restless Leg Syndrome is that symptoms begin or worsen during periods of rest or inactivity, especially when sitting or lying down. The symptoms are often relieved by movement, which is why people with RLS frequently find themselves pacing or shifting their legs during periods of rest. D. Symptoms become worse in the evening or night: This statement is true. The symptoms of RLS tend to worsen during the evening or night, particularly when the individual is preparing to sleep or is lying down for long periods. This worsening of symptoms at night is a critical component of the diagnostic criteria for RLS.

questions.text: A 48-years old man complains of pronounced shaking(4-8 hz) of both his left and right hands and head subsides during walking, after taking an alcoholic drink, and after treatment with the ?- adrenergic antagonist propranolol, but it gets exaggerated during states of anxiety. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Essential tremor. The symptoms described are most consistent with essential tremor, which is characterized by a postural and action tremor, often affecting both hands and the head. The tremor is typically in the 4-8 Hz range, as mentioned in the question. The key features supporting this diagnosis include: The tremor subsides with walking: Essential tremor often improves with movement. The tremor improves after alcohol consumption: Alcohol can reduce tremor severity in many cases of essential tremor, which is a classic sign. The tremor worsens with anxiety: Emotional stress and anxiety can exacerbate essential tremor. The response to propranolol: Propranolol, a beta-blocker, is a first-line treatment for essential tremor, which suggests this diagnosis. Why other options are incorrect: A. Parkinson disease: This statement is incorrect because Parkinson’s disease typically presents with a resting tremor, which is different from the action or postural tremor seen in essential tremor. The tremor in Parkinson’s disease usually does not improve with walking and does not get exacerbated by anxiety or relieved by alcohol. Additionally, Parkinson’s disease involves other motor features such as bradykinesia (slowness of movement), rigidity, and postural instability, none of which are mentioned here. C. Dystonia: This statement is incorrect because dystonia involves abnormal muscle contractions that cause twisting or repetitive movements or postures, rather than the rhythmic tremor seen in essential tremor. While dystonia can affect the hands or head, it is not characterized by a tremor that improves with movement or alcohol and is generally not relieved by propranolol. D. Cerebellar ataxia: This statement is incorrect because cerebellar ataxia presents with coordination difficulties, unsteady gait, and dysmetria (inability to control the range of movement), not tremors that improve with walking. Cerebellar tremors are typically not relieved by alcohol, and the characteristic tremor in cerebellar ataxia is typically irregular and worse with movement, which is not consistent with the pattern described here.

questions.text: Rapid, repetititve, coordinated and stereotyped movements, most of which can be mimicked are known as:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Tics. The description of rapid, repetitive, coordinated, and stereotyped movements that can be mimicked is most consistent with tics. Tics are involuntary, sudden, repetitive movements or vocalizations that can often be voluntarily suppressed for a brief time but generally occur in a stereotyped manner. These movements can be motor (e.g., eye blinking, head jerking) or vocal (e.g., grunting, throat clearing). One of the hallmark features of tics is that they can be mimicked, meaning that other individuals can imitate them, often in a playful or involuntary manner. Why other options are incorrect: A. Chorea: Chorea involves involuntary, jerky, and unpredictable movements that are typically not repetitive or stereotyped. Unlike tics, chorea is often associated with dancing-like movements that are irregular and seem purposeless, occurring in conditions such as Huntington’s disease. Chorea is not characterized by mimicking of movements in the same way as tics. B. Ballism: Ballism is characterized by large, violent, and flinging movements that typically affect the limbs, especially the arms, and are not repetitive and stereotyped in the same way as tics. Ballism often results from a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus and is not associated with movements that can be mimicked. The movements in ballism are usually more forceful and less coordinated. C. Athetosis: Athetosis involves slow, writhing movements that are often involuntary and affect the hands and feet, leading to abnormal postures. While it is stereotyped, it is not as rapid, repetitive, or coordinated as tics, and it is not typically associated with mimicking. Athetosis is seen in conditions like cerebral palsy and basal ganglia dysfunction.

questions.text: Athetoid movements are most marked in the:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Distal part of extremities. Athetoid movements, characterized by slow, writhing, and involuntary movements, are most marked in the distal parts of the extremities (i.e., the hands, fingers, and feet). These movements are often seen in conditions like cerebral palsy, particularly in individuals with basal ganglia dysfunction. The hands and feet are most affected because they have more fine motor control, making them more prone to these types of abnormal movements. Athetoid movements are typically less prominent in the proximal parts of the limbs or the trunk. Why other options are incorrect: A. Face: While facial dystonia or other abnormal movements can occur in the face, athetoid movements are not typically most marked in the face. The face might exhibit some abnormal movements, like grimacing or lip smacking, but in the case of athetoid movements, they are more prominent in the distal limbs. B. Trunk: Athetoid movements are generally less marked in the trunk, as the trunk tends to be less affected by these types of slow, writhing movements. The trunk might experience postural abnormalities or dystonic movements, but it is not the primary site of athetoid movements. C. Proximal part of extremities: Athetoid movements tend to be less prominent in the proximal parts of the extremities (such as the shoulders, thighs, or upper arms). While they may occasionally occur in the proximal muscles, the movements are typically more noticeable in the distal extremities.

questions.text: Match the following: Lesion in Movement I) Caudate nucleus (i) Hemiballismus II) Subthalamic nuclei (ii) Chorea III) Lenticular nucleus (iii) Athetosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) I (ii), II (i), III (iii). This matching is based on the specific types of movement disorders caused by lesions in different structures of the basal ganglia: I) Caudate nucleus (ii) Chorea: The caudate nucleus is primarily associated with chorea, a type of involuntary, rapid, and irregular movement. Chorea is often seen in conditions like Huntington’s disease, where the caudate nucleus undergoes degeneration. II) Subthalamic nuclei (i) Hemiballismus: The subthalamic nucleus is involved in hemiballismus, a movement disorder characterized by violent, flinging, and involuntary movements of one side of the body. Hemiballismus occurs due to damage to the subthalamic nucleus, usually as a result of a stroke. III) Lenticular nucleus (iii) Athetosis: The lenticular nucleus, which includes the putamen and globus pallidus, is associated with athetoid movements. Athetosis consists of slow, writhing, and twisting movements, typically affecting the hands and feet, and is often due to lesions in the lenticular nucleus. Why other options are incorrect: A. I (i), II (ii), III (iii): This option is incorrect because the caudate nucleus is associated with chorea (not hemiballismus), and the subthalamic nucleus causes hemiballismus (not chorea). The correct associations are reversed in this option. B. I (ii), II (iii), III (i): This option is incorrect because the lenticular nucleus is associated with athetoid movements (not chorea). Additionally, the subthalamic nucleus causes hemiballismus, not athetosis, and the caudate nucleus causes chorea, not hemiballismus. C. I (iii), II (i), III (ii): This option is incorrect because it mismatches the basal ganglia structures and the movements. The caudate nucleus is associated with chorea (not athetosis), and the lenticular nucleus is associated with athetoid movements (not chorea). The subthalamic nucleus causes hemiballismus (not athetosis).

questions.text: Sudden brief shock like jerkey movements involving groups of muscles with normal consciousness are called as
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Myoclonus. Myoclonus refers to sudden, brief, shock-like jerky movements that involve groups of muscles. These movements are often described as “shock-like” or “jolts”, and they occur involuntarily. Myoclonus can occur as a result of a variety of causes, such as neurological disorders or metabolic issues, and is characterized by normal consciousness. The movements are brief and localized but can involve different muscle groups. They are often seen in conditions like epilepsy, metabolic disturbances, or as a side effect of medications. Why other options are incorrect: A. Hemiballismus: Hemiballismus is characterized by violent, flinging movements of one side of the body, typically involving the limbs. These movements are much larger and more forceful than myoclonus and are usually due to a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus. Unlike myoclonus, hemiballismus is not brief or shock-like, and it typically involves extreme involuntary movement rather than jerks. C. Athetosis: Athetosis involves slow, writhing, twisting movements, often affecting the hands and feet. These movements are continuous and lack the brief shock-like nature seen in myoclonus. Athetosis is typically associated with basal ganglia lesions and is not characterized by sudden, jerky movements. D. Chorea: Chorea consists of rapid, irregular, and jerky movements that appear random and are often involuntary. While similar to myoclonus in terms of involuntary movement, chorea is typically more continuous and irregular, rather than sudden, brief, and shock-like. Chorea often involves dancing-like movements and is typically associated with conditions such as Huntington’s disease.

questions.text: “Alien hand” phenomenon is a feature of?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Corticobasal Degeneration (CBD). The "alien hand phenomenon" is a characteristic feature of corticobasal degeneration (CBD), a rare neurodegenerative disorder. In this condition, a person may experience a sensation that one of their hands is acting independently, as if it has a mind of its own. The affected hand may perform actions without the person being able to control it, such as grabbing objects or performing gestures without conscious intention. This phenomenon is thought to result from dysfunction in the parietal cortex and basal ganglia, which are involved in motor control and the awareness of one's body. Why other options are incorrect: A. Progressive Supranuclear Palsy (PSP): While progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) shares some clinical features with CBD, such as motor dysfunction and cognitive impairment, the alien hand phenomenon is not a hallmark feature of PSP. PSP primarily involves issues with gaze palsy, postural instability, and other motor symptoms, but alien hand syndrome is not commonly seen in PSP. B. Lewy Body Dementia (LBD): Lewy body dementia (LBD) involves fluctuating cognition, visual hallucinations, and parkinsonism, but the alien hand phenomenon is not a typical feature of LBD. LBD is more commonly associated with cognitive symptoms, such as memory loss and confusion, along with motor symptoms like tremors and rigidity, but alien hand syndrome is not a defining characteristic of this condition. D. Alzheimer’s Dementia: Alzheimer’s dementia is characterized by progressive memory loss, confusion, and changes in behavior, but it does not typically present with the alien hand phenomenon. While Alzheimer's involves significant brain changes, particularly in the hippocampus and cortex, it does not affect the motor control systems in a way that would cause this specific phenomenon.
